assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden database authentication with default credentials removed, strong passwords (≥16 chars), key-based auth, MFA for admin, and no anonymous access?
verification: Review default credential removal (postgres, root, admin passwords changed/removed)
Check strong password policy (≥16 chars, complexity, no dictionary words)
Verify key-based authentication (prefer certificate/key-based over passwords)
Confirm MFA for administrative database access (100% admin accounts)
Review anonymous access disabled (no anonymous/guest accounts)
evidence: Default credential removal documentation (all defaults changed/removed)
Password policy (≥16 chars, complexity requirements, dictionary exclusion)
Key-based authentication configuration (certificate/key auth enabled)
Admin MFA enforcement (100% admin accounts require MFA)
Anonymous access configuration (disabled, no guest accounts)

scoring.yes_if: Default credentials removed, strong passwords (≥16 chars, complexity), key-based auth preferred, 100% admin MFA, anonymous access disabled
scoring.partial_if: Default credentials removed but passwords <16 chars or <100% admin MFA or anonymous access exists
scoring.no_if: Default credentials present or passwords <12 chars or no admin MFA or anonymous access allowed

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden database network access with private IPs only (never 0.0.0.0), firewall rules (allow required sources only), no public access, and VPN/bastion for admin access?
verification: Review database binding (private IPs only, never 0.0.0.0 all interfaces)
Check firewall rules (allow only required sources: application servers, deny all else)
Verify no public internet exposure (databases never publicly accessible)
Confirm VPN/bastion admin access (require VPN or bastion host for administrative access)
Review network segmentation (databases isolated from general network)
evidence: Database binding configuration (private IPs, not 0.0.0.0)
Firewall rules (allow list: application servers, deny all default)
Public access validation (no databases publicly accessible, scans confirm)
VPN/bastion requirement (administrative access requires VPN or bastion)
Network segmentation (database network isolated)

scoring.yes_if: Private IPs only (never 0.0.0.0), firewall allow list (application servers only, deny default), no public access (validated), VPN/bastion admin access required, network segmentation
scoring.partial_if: Private IPs but limited firewall rules or VPN optional (not required) for admin or limited segmentation
scoring.no_if: 0.0.0.0 binding or no firewall rules or public access found or no VPN/bastion requirement

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement database encryption with TDE at rest (AES-256, external KMS, annual key rotation) and TLS in transit (TLS 1.3 or 1.2+, certificate validation, strong cipher suites)?
verification: Review encryption at rest (Transparent Data Encryption: PostgreSQL pgcrypto, MySQL InnoDB, SQL Server TDE, MongoDB encryption; AES-256 algorithm)
Check key management (external KMS: AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault; annual key rotation)
Verify encryption in transit (TLS for all database connections: TLS 1.3 preferred, TLS 1.2 minimum)
Confirm certificate validation (enforce validation, reject self-signed certificates)
Review cipher suites (strong cipher suites only, no weak ciphers)
evidence: Encryption at rest configuration (TDE enabled: PostgreSQL, MySQL, SQL Server, MongoDB; AES-256)
KMS integration (external KMS: AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault; annual key rotation policy)
TLS configuration (TLS 1.3 or 1.2+ for all database connections)
Certificate validation (enforced, self-signed rejected)
Cipher suite configuration (strong cipher suites only, weak ciphers disabled)

scoring.yes_if: TDE at rest (AES-256, all databases), external KMS (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, annual rotation), TLS in transit (TLS 1.3 or 1.2+, all connections), certificate validation (enforced, self-signed rejected), strong cipher suites
scoring.partial_if: TDE enabled but internal key management (not external KMS) or TLS 1.2 only or limited certificate validation
scoring.no_if: No TDE or no encryption in transit or TLS <1.2 or self-signed certs accepted

assessment_criteria.question: Do you enforce least privilege database authorization with application accounts (required permissions only), read-only accounts, no SUPERUSER for applications, row-level security, and column-level security for sensitive data?
verification: Review application account permissions (grant only required: SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE on specific tables, not SUPERUSER)
Check read-only accounts (separate accounts for analytics, reporting with read-only permissions)
Verify SUPERUSER restriction (no SUPERUSER or root for application accounts)
Confirm row-level security (RLS for multi-tenant databases: users see only their data)
Review column-level security (encrypt or restrict access to sensitive columns: PII, PHI, PCI)
evidence: Application account permissions (least privilege: required tables/operations only, no SUPERUSER)
Read-only account configuration (analytics, reporting accounts with read-only permissions)
SUPERUSER restriction policy (application accounts never SUPERUSER or root)
Row-level security implementation (RLS for multi-tenant: user data isolation)
Column-level security (sensitive columns: PII, PHI, PCI encrypted or access restricted)

scoring.yes_if: Application accounts least privilege (required permissions only, no SUPERUSER), read-only accounts (analytics, reporting), row-level security (multi-tenant isolation), column-level security (PII, PHI, PCI protected)
scoring.partial_if: Least privilege but no read-only accounts or no RLS or limited column-level security
scoring.no_if: Application accounts with SUPERUSER or excessive permissions or no RLS or no column-level security

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden database configuration with CIS Benchmarks, unnecessary features disabled, query logging for sensitive tables, connection limits, and patching SLA (critical ≤48h, high ≤7d)?
verification: Review CIS Benchmark compliance (CIS PostgreSQL, MySQL, MongoDB, SQL Server applied)
Check unnecessary features disabled (remote file access, external scripts, xp_cmdshell)
Verify query logging (enabled for sensitive tables: PII, PHI, PCI access logged)
Confirm connection limits (prevent resource exhaustion, idle/query timeouts configured)
Review patching SLA (critical patches ≤48 hours, high ≤7 days, medium ≤30 days; tested in staging before production)
evidence: CIS Benchmark compliance (CIS PostgreSQL, MySQL, MongoDB, SQL Server applied and validated)
Disabled features documentation (remote file access, external scripts, xp_cmdshell disabled)
Query logging configuration (sensitive tables: PII, PHI, PCI logging enabled)
Connection limit configuration (resource limits, idle timeout, query timeout)
Patching policy and compliance (critical ≤48h, high ≤7d, medium ≤30d; staging testing)

scoring.yes_if: CIS Benchmarks applied (PostgreSQL, MySQL, MongoDB, SQL Server), unnecessary features disabled, sensitive table query logging, connection limits (resource, timeout), patching SLA (critical ≤48h, high ≤7d, staging tested)
scoring.partial_if: CIS Benchmarks applied but features not disabled or no query logging or patching SLA not met (critical ≤7d)
scoring.no_if: No CIS Benchmarks or unnecessary features enabled or no query logging or patching >14d for critical

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden object storage (S3, Azure Blob, GCS) with public access blocked, encryption (SSE-KMS/CMEK at rest, HTTPS in transit), least privilege IAM, versioning, and access logging?
verification: Review public access blocking (AWS S3 Block Public Access account+bucket level, Azure Blob containers private, GCS buckets private; validated with ScoutSuite/Prowler)
Check encryption at rest (AWS S3 SSE-KMS customer-managed keys not SSE-S3, Azure Blob customer-managed Key Vault keys, GCS CMEK; bucket policies require encryption reject unencrypted uploads)
Verify encryption in transit (HTTPS required, deny HTTP requests, TLS 1.2+)
Confirm least privilege IAM (minimal permissions: read-only vs write, explicit actions not s3:* or storage.*, time-limited pre-signed URLs)
Review versioning and logging (versioning enabled for deletion/ransomware protection, S3 Access Logging/CloudTrail, Azure Storage Analytics, GCS Access Logs to SIEM)
evidence: Public access blocking (S3 Block Public Access, Azure Blob private, GCS private; ScoutSuite/Prowler scans confirm no public buckets)
Encryption at rest (SSE-KMS/CMEK customer-managed keys, bucket policies reject unencrypted)
Encryption in transit (HTTPS required, HTTP denied, TLS 1.2+)
Least privilege IAM (minimal permissions, explicit actions, time-limited pre-signed URLs)
Versioning and access logging (versioning enabled, access logs to SIEM)

scoring.yes_if: Public access blocked (S3/Azure/GCS, validated), encryption at rest (SSE-KMS/CMEK customer-managed, bucket policies reject unencrypted), encryption in transit (HTTPS required, HTTP denied, TLS 1.2+), least privilege IAM (minimal, explicit, time-limited URLs), versioning + logging (enabled, SIEM integration)
scoring.partial_if: Public access blocked but SSE-S3 (not customer-managed) or HTTP allowed or excessive IAM (s3:*) or no versioning or no logging
scoring.no_if: Public buckets found or no encryption or HTTP allowed or wildcard IAM or no versioning

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden data lake/warehouse platforms with strong authentication (Kerberos for Hadoop, SSO+MFA for cloud warehouses), encryption (at rest+in transit), fine-grained access control (column/row-level, dynamic masking), and private network isolation?
verification: Review authentication hardening (Hadoop: Kerberos not simple auth in production; Cloud warehouses: SSO integration SAML/OAuth, MFA for admin accounts)
Check encryption (at rest: HDFS, S3, warehouse storage encrypted; in transit: TLS for all client-server, server-server communication)

Verify fine-grained access control (column-level, row-level security: Snowflake RLS, BigQuery column-level, Redshift column-level encryption; least privilege: required tables/columns/rows only; dynamic masking for unauthorized users)
Confirm network isolation (no public access: private endpoints, VPC peering; network segmentation: data platform isolated from general network)
evidence: Authentication configuration (Hadoop Kerberos, cloud warehouses SSO+MFA)
Encryption configuration (at rest: HDFS/S3/warehouse; in transit: TLS all connections)
Fine-grained access control (column/row-level: Snowflake RLS, BigQuery, Redshift; least privilege; dynamic masking)
Network isolation (private endpoints, VPC peering, segmentation from general network)

scoring.yes_if: Strong authentication (Hadoop Kerberos, cloud SSO+MFA), encryption (at rest+in transit all connections), fine-grained access (column/row-level: Snowflake RLS/BigQuery/Redshift, least privilege, dynamic masking), network isolation (private endpoints, segmentation)
scoring.partial_if: Authentication hardened but no MFA or encryption partial (at rest or in transit) or limited access control (table-level only) or limited network isolation
scoring.no_if: No authentication hardening or no encryption or no access control or public access

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden file shares (NFS, SMB) with access restrictions (specific IPs/hosts), encryption (NFSv4 Kerberos, SMB3 encryption), authentication (no anonymous), and least privilege permissions?
verification: Review access restrictions (NFS exports limited to specific IPs/hosts, SMB ACLs restrict access)
Check encryption (NFSv4 with Kerberos, SMB3 encryption enabled)
Verify authentication (no anonymous shares, authentication required for all access)
Confirm least privilege permissions (read-only where possible, write only when required)
evidence: File share access restrictions (NFS exports, SMB ACLs limited to specific IPs/hosts)
Encryption configuration (NFSv4 Kerberos, SMB3 encryption enabled)
Authentication enforcement (no anonymous shares, authentication required)
Least privilege permissions (read-only default, write only when required)

scoring.yes_if: Access restricted (specific IPs/hosts: NFS exports, SMB ACLs), encryption (NFSv4 Kerberos, SMB3), authentication required (no anonymous), least privilege (read-only default)
scoring.partial_if: Access restrictions but no encryption or authentication optional (anonymous allowed) or excessive permissions (write default)
scoring.no_if: No access restrictions or no encryption or anonymous shares or excessive permissions

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement encryption at rest with full-disk encryption (LUKS, BitLocker, FileVault), application-level encryption (sensitive columns via libraries, keys in KMS), and strong algorithms (AES-256-GCM, avoid deprecated)?
verification: Review full-disk encryption (LUKS for Linux, BitLocker for Windows, FileVault for macOS; cloud: encrypted EBS, Azure disks, GCP disks)
Check application-level encryption (sensitive columns: credit card, SSN, PII fields; libraries: NaCl, libsodium, AWS Encryption SDK; keys in KMS not database)
Verify algorithm selection (symmetric: AES-256-GCM authenticated, ChaCha20-Poly1305; asymmetric: RSA-4096, Ed25519, ECDSA P-256+; avoid deprecated: DES, 3DES, RC4, MD5, SHA-1)
evidence: Full-disk encryption (LUKS, BitLocker, FileVault; cloud encrypted volumes)
Application-level encryption (sensitive columns encrypted via NaCl/libsodium/AWS SDK, keys in KMS)
Algorithm configuration (AES-256-GCM, ChaCha20-Poly1305, RSA-4096, Ed25519; deprecated disabled: DES, 3DES, RC4, MD5, SHA-1)

scoring.yes_if: Full-disk encryption (LUKS/BitLocker/FileVault, cloud encrypted volumes), application-level encryption (sensitive columns, libraries, keys in KMS), strong algorithms (AES-256-GCM, ChaCha20-Poly1305, RSA-4096, Ed25519, deprecated disabled)
scoring.partial_if: Full-disk encryption but no application-level or keys in database (not KMS) or weak algorithms (3DES, MD5 used)
scoring.no_if: No full-disk encryption or no application-level or deprecated algorithms (DES, RC4) used

assessment_criteria.question: Do you harden TLS with strong versions (TLS 1.3 preferred, TLS 1.2 minimum, disable <1.2), strong cipher suites (ECDHE-GCM, forward secrecy, disable weak), and certificate validation (no self-signed, pinning, revocation checking)?
verification: Review TLS version (TLS 1.3 preferred, TLS 1.2 minimum; TLS 1.0, 1.1, SSLv3 disabled)
Check cipher suites (prefer: ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384, ECDHE-RSA-CHACHA20-POLY1305; disable: RC4, DES, 3DES, export ciphers, null ciphers; require ECDHE or DHE for perfect forward secrecy)
Verify certificate validation (no self-signed in production, certificate pinning for critical services, revocation checking: OCSP, CRL)
evidence: TLS version configuration (TLS 1.3 preferred, TLS 1.2 minimum; <1.2 disabled)
Cipher suite configuration (ECDHE-GCM preferred, weak disabled: RC4/DES/3DES/export/null, forward secrecy ECDHE/DHE)
Certificate validation (self-signed rejected, pinning for critical services, revocation checking OCSP/CRL)

scoring.yes_if: TLS 1.3 preferred or TLS 1.2 minimum (<1.2 disabled), strong cipher suites (ECDHE-GCM, forward secrecy ECDHE/DHE, weak disabled), certificate validation (self-signed rejected, pinning, revocation checking)
scoring.partial_if: TLS 1.2 minimum but weak ciphers allowed (3DES, RC4) or self-signed accepted (not production) or no pinning or no revocation checking
scoring.no_if: TLS <1.2 allowed or weak ciphers (RC4, DES, export) or self-signed accepted in production

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement certificate management with automated issuance (Let's Encrypt, cert-manager, ACM), rotation (≤30 day expiration alerts, automated), and private key protection (HSM/KMS, chmod 600, no sharing)?
verification: Review automated certificate issuance (Let's Encrypt, cert-manager for Kubernetes, AWS ACM; prevents expired certificates)
Check certificate rotation (monitoring: alert when ≤30 days from expiration; automation: automated rotation where possible)
Verify private key protection (storage: HSM Hardware Security Module or KMS; permissions: chmod 600 on key files; no sharing: never share private keys across systems)
evidence: Automated certificate issuance (Let's Encrypt, cert-manager, AWS ACM)
Certificate rotation (≤30 day expiration alerts, automated rotation)
Private key protection (HSM/KMS storage, chmod 600 permissions, no sharing policy)

scoring.yes_if: Automated certificate issuance (Let's Encrypt/cert-manager/ACM), rotation (≤30 day alerts, automated), private key protection (HSM/KMS, chmod 600, no sharing)
scoring.partial_if: Automated issuance but manual rotation (no automation) or keys in filesystem (not HSM/KMS) or shared keys
scoring.no_if: Manual certificate issuance or no expiration monitoring or keys not protected (chmod 644) or shared keys

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement mTLS for service-to-service communication (service mesh: Istio/Linkerd/Consul or manual) for data classification ↔ database, DLP ↔ data stores with mutual authentication and encryption?
verification: Review mTLS implementation (service mesh: Istio, Linkerd, Consul Connect or manual mTLS configuration)
Check service coverage (data classification service ↔ database, DLP ↔ data stores, internal services)
Verify mutual authentication (both client and server authenticate via certificates)
Confirm encryption (all internal traffic encrypted via mTLS)
evidence: mTLS implementation (service mesh: Istio/Linkerd/Consul or manual mTLS)
Service coverage (data classification ↔ database, DLP ↔ data stores, internal services)
Mutual authentication (client + server certificate validation)
Encryption (all internal service traffic encrypted)

scoring.yes_if: mTLS implemented (service mesh or manual), service coverage (data classification ↔ database, DLP ↔ stores, internal services), mutual authentication (client + server), encryption (all internal traffic)
scoring.partial_if: mTLS implemented but limited service coverage (<50% services) or one-way TLS (not mutual) or external traffic only
scoring.no_if: No mTLS or plaintext internal communication or no mutual authentication

assessment_criteria.question: Do you centralize key management with KMS (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, GCP Cloud KMS, HashiCorp Vault), implement key hierarchy (KEK/DEK), and enforce access control with audit logging?
verification: Review KMS usage (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, GCP Cloud KMS, HashiCorp Vault; all encryption keys: data keys, TLS keys, API keys centralized)
Check key hierarchy (KEK: Key Encryption Key master in KMS/HSM, DEK: Data Encryption Key encrypts data encrypted by KEK; benefit: rotate DEKs without re-encrypting data)
Verify access control (least privilege: only services that encrypt/decrypt access keys; IAM policies restrict key usage: kms:Encrypt, kms:Decrypt)
Confirm audit logging (log all key usage: who, which key, when, what purpose)
evidence: KMS usage (AWS KMS, Azure Key Vault, GCP Cloud KMS, Vault; all keys centralized)
Key hierarchy (KEK master in KMS/HSM, DEK encrypted by KEK)
Access control (least privilege IAM policies: kms:Encrypt, kms:Decrypt only for required services)
Audit logging (all key usage logged: who, key, when, purpose)

scoring.yes_if: KMS centralized (AWS KMS/Azure Key Vault/GCP Cloud KMS/Vault, all keys), key hierarchy (KEK/DEK, rotate DEKs without re-encrypt), access control (least privilege IAM, explicit permissions), audit logging (all usage: who, key, when, purpose)
scoring.partial_if: KMS usage but no key hierarchy (KEK/DEK) or excessive access (wildcard IAM) or limited audit logging
scoring.no_if: No KMS (keys in code/config) or no access control or no audit logging

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement key rotation with data encryption keys annually, master keys every 2-3 years, immediate rotation on compromise, and automated zero-downtime rotation?
verification: Review rotation frequency (data encryption keys DEK annually, master keys KEK every 2-3 years)
Check compromise response (immediate rotation if compromise suspected)
Verify automation (automated rotation with zero downtime, no service disruption)
Confirm rotation testing (rotation procedures tested, validated for zero downtime)
evidence: Key rotation policy (DEK annually, KEK every 2-3 years)
Compromise rotation procedure (immediate rotation on suspected compromise)
Automated rotation (zero downtime, service continuity)
Rotation testing (procedures tested, zero downtime validated)

scoring.yes_if: Rotation frequency (DEK annually, KEK 2-3 years), immediate on compromise, automated zero-downtime rotation, rotation tested
scoring.partial_if: Rotation frequency defined but manual rotation (not automated) or downtime during rotation or not tested
scoring.no_if: No rotation policy or rotation >5 years or manual rotation with downtime or not tested

assessment_criteria.question: Do you implement key backup and recovery with encrypted backups (separate KEK), separate region/account storage, documented recovery procedures, and annual testing?
verification: Review key backups (encrypted backups of keys, protected with separate KEK)
Check backup storage (separate region or account from production keys)
Verify recovery procedures (documented key recovery procedures, step-by-step instructions)
Confirm annual testing (recovery procedures tested annually, successful recovery validated)
evidence: Key backup policy (encrypted backups, separate KEK protection)
Backup storage (separate region or account from production)
Recovery procedures documentation (step-by-step key recovery instructions)
Annual testing results (recovery tested yearly, successful recovery validated)

scoring.yes_if: Encrypted key backups (separate KEK), separate region/account storage, documented recovery procedures, annual testing (successful recovery validated)
scoring.partial_if: Key backups but same KEK (not separate) or same region as production or procedures not documented or testing <annual
scoring.no_if: No key backups or unencrypted backups or same account as production or no recovery procedures or never tested

success_metrics.target: 100% databases hardened: default credentials removed, MFA for admin, TDE at rest, TLS in transit, least privilege, CIS Benchmarks
success_metrics.measurement: Database hardening compliance % = (Hardened databases / Total databases) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Database configuration audits, CIS Benchmark scans
success_metrics.validation: CIS Benchmark scans validate compliance, audits confirm MFA + TDE + TLS

success_metrics.target: 100% object storage hardened: no public access, SSE-KMS/CMEK at rest, HTTPS in transit, least privilege IAM, versioning
success_metrics.measurement: Object storage security % = (Hardened buckets / Total buckets) × 100
success_metrics.validation: ScoutSuite/Prowler scans confirm no public buckets, SSE-KMS/CMEK enforced

success_metrics.target: 100% sensitive data encrypted: full-disk encryption, TDE at rest, TLS in transit (TLS 1.3 or 1.2+), strong algorithms
success_metrics.measurement: Encryption coverage % = (Encrypted data stores / Total data stores) × 100
success_metrics.validation: Audits confirm 100% encryption: full-disk, TDE, TLS 1.2+

success_metrics.target: 100% services use TLS 1.3 or 1.2+, strong cipher suites, certificate validation, no self-signed in production
success_metrics.validation: TLS scans confirm TLS 1.2+, strong ciphers, no self-signed

success_metrics.target: 100% encryption keys in KMS, key hierarchy (KEK/DEK), least privilege access, audit logging
success_metrics.measurement: Key centralization % = (Keys in KMS / Total keys) × 100
success_metrics.validation: Audits confirm 100% keys in KMS, access control enforced

success_metrics.target: 100% key rotation compliant: DEK annually, KEK 2-3 years, automated zero-downtime
success_metrics.measurement: Rotation compliance % = (Keys rotated on schedule / Total keys) × 100
success_metrics.data_source: Key rotation logs, KMS audit logs
success_metrics.baseline: Key rotation policy (DEK annually, KEK 2-3 years)
success_metrics.validation: Rotation logs confirm automated rotation on schedule, zero downtime

success_metrics.target: 100% data access least privilege: database permissions minimal, object storage IAM minimal, no SUPERUSER for applications
success_metrics.measurement: Least privilege compliance % = (Least privilege accounts / Total accounts) × 100
success_metrics.validation: Audits confirm least privilege, no SUPERUSER for applications, minimal IAM
